Media: The New York Times
Review: A big bearhug of a musical...Even the most stalwart cynics may have trouble staying dry-eyed during this portrait of heroic hospitality under extraordinary pressure...'Come From Away' is smarter than it first appears...The show covers a vast expanse of sensitive material with a respect for its complexity...It sustains an air of improvisational urgency, which feels appropriate to a show about making do in crisis, and it doesn<U+2019>t linger on obvious moments of heartbreak and humanity.

Media: BroadwayWorld
Review: 'Come From Away,' the inspiring, funny and kick-ass beautiful new musical...takes a true story that began on September 11th, 2001, and tells it in an exhilarating fashion that celebrates decency and human kindness...Director Christopher Ashley's production seamlessly moves from tense moments to humorous ones to unabashedly joyous ones...As long as 'Come From Away' is playing on Broadway, I will recommend it to everyone. Everyone.

Media: Variety
Review: The cast is a hearty group and so good-natured they really put the lyrics across...Ashley keeps the traffic moving smartly...But there<U+2019>s no getting away from it<U+2014>as broad representatives from both camps of hosts and guests, the characters have no character...By the end of the show, the characters are scarcely more defined than they were at the beginning, and the monotonous music may be pounding on your head. But the intentions of the show are so heartfelt.

Media: Time Out New York
Review: A swelling heart of a musical...'Come from Away's' multiple narratives mostly have low stakes...When it touches on weightier concerns it falters; it is better at celebrating less consequential things...Under Christopher Ashley<U+2019>s fluid direction, the 12 versatile actors form a true ensemble cast...Despite minor stumbles of craft, 'Come from Away' makes a persuasive case for the value of good intentions. For this kind of uplift you don<U+2019>t need planes.

Media: Theatermania
Review: A show that everybody needs to see...A thoroughly moving experience, brimming with humanity and tolerance. Admittedly, it's not without its flaws; Sankoff and Hein's sweet Celtic melodies have a tendency to blend in together, and the book could afford to flesh out certain situations with greater depth. But Ashley's fast-paced staging is mesmerizing, Devine's foot-stomping choreography is joyful, and an awesome onstage jam band plays Eriksmoen's driving orchestrations with excitement.

Media: The Hollywood Reporter
Review: Creators Sankoff and Hein have crafted a heartwarming and thoroughly entertaining musical...Despite the doubling and tripling of roles, the numerous characters are all vividly rendered, thanks to the skillfulness of the writing and performances...Although not particularly memorable, the music proves consistently engaging and serves the story line beautifully...Serving as a welcome reminder of people<U+2019>s inherent goodness, 'Come From Away' is the feel-good show of the season.

Media: Lighting & Sound America
Review: Without making a fuss or employing dubious dazzlements, stirs one to the core...Under Christopher Ashley's swiftly paced, emotionally astute direction, a company of only twelve portrays everyone with seeming effortlessness...There are moments when, in its portrayal of such universal goodwill, 'Come From Away' flirts with becoming cutesy or too insistently upbeat; time and again, however, it steps back from the brink, reminding us that a world-shaking tragedy is taking place.

Media: The Huffington Post
Review: <U+201C>Altogether different and altogether gripping. Written with heart and skill by Sankoff and Hein<U+2026>creatively and lucidly directed by Christopher Ashley, and performed by a wildly talented cast...The piece is not merely uplifting but entertaining as well...What looks to be the significant success of this new musical stems from the fact that even the most cynical among us is likely to be deeply touched.

Media: DC Theatre Scene
Review: I was worried that 'Come From Away' would be triggering. But the exact opposite occurred. The Canadian songwriting team of Sankoff and Hein are so eager to please that 'Come From Away' keeps a safe distance from the horror of 9/11...'Come From Away' is certainly feel good<U+2013>also rhythmic, well staged, often funny...Much of the appeal of 'Come From Away' comes not from individual performances but from the precise and lively ensemble work, aided by an eight-piece band.

Media: Theater Life
Review: <U+201C>Yes, the book is episodic and the songs are a bit treacly here and there...However, Sankoff and Hein resist these Lifetime-TV temptations for the most part, leavening syrupy <U+2018>feel-good<U+2019> tropes with sharp wit and memorable, Gaelic-flavored music. Director Ashley keeps the many characters and settings clear with a precise, fluid direction and strong, detail-laden performances<U+2026>'Come From Away' offers a reassuring and heartening take on the earth-shattering event.

Media: Front Row Center
Review: Greater than the sum of its parts. The script is iffy. The music is not exceptional. The sound is so loud that the lyrics are often unintelligible. The talent, it should be noted is not iffy one little bit...No one will leave untouched by this show...The cast is beautifully directed and choreographed. Each actor plays more than one part, and their characterizations are so defined that we never, not for an instant, are lost in the transitions.

Media: Talkin' Broadway
Review: 'Come From Away' can't escape its own generic nature; it lacks the necessary fuel. The story doesn't stun...What they have done is make the best of a bad arrangement. They've created one of the most energized and exhilarating evenings of static I've ever seen...Of the many things 'Come From Away' wants to be about, September 11 is pretty far down on the list. That robs it of the urgency, authenticity, and soul it would need to be a grand trek rather than a mildly pleasant detour.

Media: The Wall Street Journal
Review: A gushily sentimental piece of theatrical yard goods that makes every mistake a musical can make...The results play like a volume of oral-history transcripts set to music, and the decision of the authors not to focus tightly on specific characters results in a cluttered, top-heavy show with too much exposition and not nearly enough development...If you<U+2019>ve been waiting breathlessly for a gooey, uplifting musical about 9/11, your dream has come true.

Media: The Huffington Post
Review: <U+201C>It seems almost churlish to take apart such a blandly friendly show like <U+2018>Come From Away.<U+2019> But bland it is, from the book to the songs to the choreography and pretty much every performance. The inescapable problem is that there is no dramatic story to tell<U+2026>Any possibilities for tension are mostly ignored<U+2026>Many of the characters are based on real people but they all feel anonymous.

Media: AM New York
Review: Sunny and overstuffed but well-meaning...It<U+2019>s a heartwarming story told with high energy, not to mention an effective seminar on crisis management and a persuasive advertisement for Canadian tourism...But good intentions aside, 'Come From Away' has the depth of a Hallmark card and a pub rock score that is generic and unmemorable. In attempting to keep track of so many different people at once without pause, few receive more than superficial treatment.

Media: New York Magazine / Vulture
Review: By no means the best musical on Broadway, but it<U+2019>s surely the goodest...The production, tightly directed by Ashley, does its damnedest to knock you into submission. The songs are pleasant...In facing the problem of making its story palatable as a stage work, 'Come From Away,' despite its good heart, has possibly lost its way...That it may succeed in making the audience cry is a testament to its fine qualities,  which are sufficient to position 'Come From Away' as a possible feel-good hit.

Media: New York Daily News
Review: A big-hearted and crowd-pleasing musical...It's a story that sings...While rousing and rich in harmony, the music suffers from sameness and a sound mix that obscures lyrics...Quips are balanced with serious moments revolving around personal crises and cultural collisions, but the show could do with a bit more introspection...Director Ashley guides the excellent cast and energizing staging...It's a singing reminder that when things are at their worst, people can be at their best.

Media: Times Square Chronicles
Review: This feel-good musical is infectious, enchanting and just what this country needs right now...Director Christopher Ashley and his amazing 12-member cast recreate the story...Each have their moment to shine but they are a true ensemble...It is hard not to be moved. Even as I am writing this I find myself choking up...'Come From Away' is tuneful, smart and heartfelt, and is sure to have you leaving the theatre feeling just a little bit more positive than when you entered.

Media: Deadline
Review: Charming and emotionally resonant...'Come From Away' speaks the common language of just folks, and it sings and dances with the authentic inspiration of Newfoundland<U+2019>s Celtic-based music...Hein and Sarnoff are not Sondheim. The folksy songs in 'Come From Away' are nearly all expository rather than revelatory...The show, staged with kinetic enthusiasm by Christopher Ashley, positively reeks of integrity<U+2013>positive being the operative word.

Media: CurtainUp
Review: There's certainly plenty to admire about 'Come From Away'...Director Ashley has done a masterful job of insuring that the 12 actors fluidly shift back and forth between their multiple roles...The resourceful staging and non-stop energy of the performers accomplishes its intent...Unfortunately, there are more than a few things missing...None of the characters really make strong, individual impressions...The music is catchy but repetitive and so abrasively loud that it's hard hear the lyrics.

Media: Chicago Tribune
Review: The show insists on a kind of oral-history equality, constantly shifting from one narrator or protagonist to another...This was no doubt intentional...But it comes at the price of character development...The audience for this show will have been more impacted personally by the losses of Sept. 11...This show never explores that truth...To really do that, Ashley's production would have to be more willing to pause, breathe and challenge, and allow those impacted the most to come to the fore.

Media: Newsday
Review: A feel-pretty-nice musical. Think of the simple show as psychological training wheels, perhaps a way to ease us into the unbearable stories our playwrights might someday ask us to confront...The Gander people have a real untold story to tell, which Sankoff and Hein lay out with bits of overlapping narratives and folksy, stomping songs...Director Ashley gets solid, likable performances...Over five days, however, they get distracted into what feels just a bit too much like hootenanny camp.

Media: The Wrap
Review: As songwriters, this duo relies on a strong percussive element that<U+2019>s so incessant that their songs take on a militaristic flair. And they<U+2019>re also very, very loud...Dialogue is shrill and disembodied from the actors, and when the ensemble sings any of the show<U+2019>s foot-stomping anthems, the lyrics are indecipherable...Christopher Ashley directs the ground traffic, and when he finally gets all those stranded visitors back up in the air you will definitely experience their sense of relief.

Media: NorthJersey.com
Review: <U+201C>It<U+2019>s a celebration of the best human instincts, and, particularly coming at this time, doesn<U+2019>t seem at all hokey. It<U+2019>s cheering and refreshing...<U+2019>Come from Away<U+2019> tells its many-sided story in an effective, fast-moving style...The well-integrated  songs, which range literally from foot-stompers to ballads, are mostly performed by the entire company, emphasizing the theme of community...Tells its story efficiently, but also with a sense of completeness. It<U+2019>s a tale well-worth hearing.<U+201D>

Media: Front Mezz Junkies
Review: It is a refreshing, warm, and very humane tale that attends to the lump that will be in your throat, and the tears of love and compassion that will run down your cheeks, by also putting a big grin on your face...This writing team does create the most musically lovely story about that day in the most humanly way possible...Beautifully staged by the creative team, 'Come From Away' is one of the most singularly engaging new musicals to come to Broadway this spring.

Media: Beautiful, Thought-provoking, Relevant, Resonant, Touching  webman843
Review: See it if you want to see a beautifully moving story portrayed perfectly. (You will cry)
Review (Don't): Don't see it if you are looking for production value.=

Review: See it if Best ensemble on Bway evokes laughs and tears in this moving and foot-stomping musical with an overabundance of empathetic heart
Review (Don't): Don't see it if highly functional songs are not particularly memorable save for the Jenn Colella showstopper=

Media: Clever, Delightful, Refreshing  KMAC23
Review: See it if a fantastic musical with a great music, beautiful stories and lots of laughs. I can't think of a single bad thing to say.
Review (Don't): Don't see it if go see it.

Media: Clever, Must see, Entertaining, Great singing, Great staging  Cristina 3
Review: See it if You love a great ensemble cast and an interesting story.
Review (Don't): Don't see it if You want solo acts or a one person show.=

Review: See it if you want to see a strong original ensemble piece. Beautifully sung w/masterful music excellently performed on-stage by rockin' musicians.
Review (Don't): Don't see it if you have no heart. Deeply moving, sweet & loving. Hits home for all NY'ers. Amazing ensemble performs AS ONE: their unison is enthralling.=

Review: See it if you want to walk away from a show feeling better about humanity.
Review (Don't): Don't see it if you want to see a show that will make you think deeply.=

Review: See it if You want to laugh and cry while remembering an event that is scorched in our minds
Review (Don't): Don't see it if You want standard fare about fictional people and places=

Review (Don't): Don't see it if If you do not want to be reminded of 9/11 in any way shape or form. Want elaborate sets. Find actors playing multiple roles confusing.=Also I normally stay clear of anything 9/11 related. This show is about people who were impacted far away from both ground zeros. Though it brought back painful memories. It was good to see this perspective....<U+00A0>Read more Read less=

Media: Absorbing, Clever, Must see, Great singing, Great staging  ELON 6085
Review: See it if Want to see a show that is relevant and has you anxiously awaiting your chance to stand up and cheer. Great staging.
Review (Don't): Don't see it if Are easily depressed over 9/11 conversation or are easily confused by multiple stories at once.=

Review: See it if you want to see an expertly crafted, Celtic-accented, and feet stomping-filled show on a portrait of heroic hospitality from September 2001
Review (Don't): Don't see it if you want to miss a show with the biggest heart this season, with a cast of 12 telling the individual, diverse, and complex lives of hundreds=

Review: See it if you want to see a fully original musical staged by a scrappy team of actors all working in perfect harmony
Review (Don't): Don't see it if the subject matter is not one that you want to re-visit=

Review: See it if you were alive during 9/11, enjoy learning about the lesser-known details of history, or are moved by human kindness with no ulterior motive
Review (Don't): Don't see it if you have a fear of flying, or if you can't handle discussion of terrorist activity/national disasters (it's an intense thing; no shame)=

Media: Funny, Absorbing, Delightful, Enchanting, Entertaining  Ralph 5
Review: See it if Interesting story, well executed, catchy music. Entertaining.
Review (Don't): Don't see it if Interesting story, well executed, catchy music. Entertaining.=

Review: See it if You want to be deeply moved while being entertained and highly amused
Review (Don't): Don't see it if Your only concern in a musical is the music--it's perfectly good but not what the show will be remembered for=Also I didn't expect to laugh so much. Seriously, it's the funniest show I've seen in years. The cast is unanimously superb, with lots of new faces....<U+00A0>Read more Read less=

Media: Intelligent, Relevant, Resonant, Entertaining, Great singing  Maya B
Review: See it if You want to see an inspiring, heartwarming, uplifting story based off of a true event.
Review (Don't): Don't see it if you don't want to see a show based off of an event that occurred as a result of 9/11.=

Media: Absorbing, Great writing, Great singing, Enjoyable, Touching  Izagma
Review: See it if You are interested in a good play about a true story of hospitality in times of need after 9/11.
Review (Don't): Don't see it if Stories about 9/11 are too close fir comfort or you are not ready gor a positive 9/12 story.=

Review: See it if Extremely well staged and acted. Well told story that keeps you involved
Review (Don't): Don't see it if You are expecting to be tremendously moved as some critics felt. It was very enjoyable but I expected more.=

Media: Great acting, Relevant, Great singing  TheaterGeekNYC
Review: See it if One of those shows that one finds delightful with a lot of hear. Great singing, and stirs in you the power of the human connection.
Review (Don't): Don't see it if conceptual and minimalist staging bothers you.=

Media: Must see, Riveting, Great writing, Great singing, Great staging  CJ S
Review: See it if A show about the human spirit. Do yourself a favor and be a part of this experience.
Review (Don't): Don't see it if There is absolutely no reason. You will be a kinder, empathetic, and selfless person when you leave the theatre.=

Review: See it if You are a thoughtful, caring human being who cares about your fellow human beings. If you voted for Trump, this might be the cure.
Review (Don't): Don't see it if All you want to do is build a wall and are so closed minded you are not willing to see a better way.=

Media: Absorbing, Ambitious, Refreshing, Great staging  actorguy
Review: See it if you want to see the show that will give DEH a run for it's money at the Tony awards. Heartfelt. Beautiful staging/direction
Review (Don't): Don't see it if you are looking for a flashy musical.=

Media: Absorbing, Must see, Refreshing, Great writing, Great staging  Jennzy
Review: See it if you want to witness a beautiful story and a great cast as well!
Review (Don't): Don't see it if you want to see a play!=

Media: Thought-provoking, Cliched, Overrated, Glib, Sentimental  JimDM
Review: See it if You want a folksy musical about the effects of 9/11 on one small town, docu-drama style.
Review (Don't): Don't see it if You were in NYC on 9/11. Or you want your characters to feel developed. Or any sense of the scale of the tragedy. It felt glib and dishonest=

Media: Refreshing, Entertaining, Great singing, Touching  Heltondrew
Review: See it if You love a sense of community and great singing.
Review (Don't): Don't see it if You don't like smiling=

Media: Funny, Clever, Delightful, Must see, Entertaining  EM1408
Review: See it if You love a great ensemble piece with lively music
Review (Don't): Don't see it if You would prefer a focused piece with one major character arc=

Media: Bob's Theater Blog
Review: An excellent ensemble of twelve play both the residents and the guests, changing roles faster than you can blink...The style of the music is mainly Celtic folk. Many of the songs sounded alike to my untrained ear. There is one lovely number where several passengers pray, each according to his or her custom....Christopher Ashley<U+2019>s direction keeps things flowing smoothly...Judging from the audience<U+2019>s enthusiasm, Broadway will welcome this feel-good musical.

Media: WNBC
Review: A dignified, often funny new musical...Some of the characters are real; others are recognized to be composite sketches of the people whom writers Sankoff and Hein met. Inevitably, many of the portrayals feel like stock characters but the acting is excellent all around...'Come From Away' manages to find a spiritual angle to a horrific story, depicting the goodness in humanity while still allowing us room for the feelings of loneliness and fear that will always be connected to that time.

Media: NY1
Review: The beautifully crafted musical leaves us not just feeling good, we<U+2019>re transported on a wave of hope for humanity...A huge bravo to director Ashley who masterfully orchestrated the complex work...Sankoff and Hein created this wonderful work with a moving score that's both melodic and rousing...Every member of this extraordinary collaboration deserves the highest praise. With great warmth and humor, 'Come From Away' is a soul-stirring antidote to the terrors we face near and far.

Media: TheaterScene.net
Review: For once a 'feel-good' musical that also has depth and resonance! 'Come From Away' at the Gerald Schoenfeld Theatre takes on one of the darkest periods in our contemporary history and spins it into a goldmine of goodwill, compassion and gentle surprises.

Media: Financial Times (UK)
Review: <U+201C>The small, multitasking ensemble certainly do their damnedest to keep looking on the bright side of world-historical catastrophe...But the show<U+2019>s ode to triumph in the face of adversity quickly becomes repetitive in the absence of any discernible attempt to grapple with the full horror of the attacks<U+2026>And there<U+2019>s little sense of pathos in Sankoff and Hein<U+2019>s jaunty, Celtic rock-themed score, which made me feel as if I had been locked in a particularly hellish ersatz Irish pub.<U+201D>

Media: The Washington Post
Review: <U+201C>The lump that forms in your throat in the opening minutes is the physiological confirmation that this effervescent musical, enveloped in Canadian good will, is an antidote for what ails the American soul...The alternating stories of the townspeople and the strangers in their midst are communicated vivaciously by book and songwriters Sankoff and Hein, in a bracingly kinetic production directed by Christopher Ashley, doing some of the most impressive work of his career. <U+201D>

Media: Towleroad
Review: Alternately heartwarming and heartbreaking, 'Come From Away' reminds us of the simple truth that tragedy sometimes brings out the best in people. It<U+2019>s a story we don<U+2019>t hear often enough, and, yes, one worth going on about in song...It<U+2019>s almost impossible to sit through 'Come From Away' and not think back to where you were on 9/11...Director Christopher Ashley<U+2019>s lean staging works in part because his subject matter is already so vivid in our collective imagination.

Media: Out Magazine
Review: The musical manages to tell this story without mawkish sentimentality or manipulation, keeping things moving with a fluid staging that incorporates group numbers, solo spots, narration, heart, humor and a finale by the band...Things are generally sunny, yet believable. Finally, a musical not based on an old movie, but on an actual occurrences<U+2014>it feels fresh and welcome.

Media: DC Metro Theater Arts
Review: Under Ashley<U+2019>s non-stop direction, the stage is constantly in motion, which is useful in that it keeps the energy high, but distracting in that it never stops long enough for us to get to know anyone very well...Taken all together, it works...'Come From Away' is an important show for our troubled times. We need honestly drawn stories of hope and good will to come from the stage...It<U+2019>s refreshing to have on the boards something as exuberant as 'Come From Away.'

Media: Theater Pizzazz
Review: It<U+2019>s an inauspicious beginning. Yet, somehow it starts to work...By the end of the show, and their visit, we are emotionally invested in each story, so much so that their departure is cathartic. And for all their stories, the town folk are just as dynamic and fascinating...What this production demonstrates, particularly through Christopher Ashley<U+2019>s expert direction, is that the sum of 'Come From Away<U+2019>s' various stories and parts make a much greater, more beautiful whole.

Media: Musical Theater Review
Review: The book, music and lyrics are the inspired work of Irene Sankoff and David Hein. With a cast of 12 backed by eight musicians, the production, for a Broadway musical, is relatively small-scale...But all of it is managed with big-time ingenuity by director Ashley...Story theatre techniques are used to the nth degree. The performers switch characters, from townspeople to passengers and back again...There are indeed a lot of upbeat goings-on...But the darker side of the events is hardly ignored.

Media: WNYC
Review: A delightful new musical...This is a story about kindness and coming together, which feels like a balm in today's bitter, divided age...The music is fierce and lively and sometimes poignant. Director Christopher Ashley pulls the magic trick of keeping all the characters straight, as they whirl in and out of different characters. 'Come From Away' is a love letter<U+2014>to Newfoundland, to New York, to what people can do if they set aside fear and hate. Don't miss it.

Media: Epoch Times
Review: A brilliant achievement...The show makes you laugh and cry at the resiliency of the human spirit...The cast, all of whom play multiple roles, are quite simply fantastic. Christopher Ashley<U+2019>s direction is letter-perfect, and Kelly Devine<U+2019>s excellent musical staging includes a rousing opening sequence that helps to establish a small-town atmosphere for Gander. Alternatively funny and profoundly moving, 'Come From Away' is a brilliant example of all that musical theater can be.

Media: Theater Life
Review: Should warm the heart of even the world<U+2019>s worst cynic. But the musical, directed by Christopher Ashley, has much more to praise. First there<U+2019>s Sankoff and Hein<U+2019>s spirited score, driving, buoyant and often tuneful, with an appropriately Celtic undertone...Then there<U+2019>s the tremendous acting of the 12-member ensemble...It is a musical about people who do their best in the worst of times. And for this we can only say thank you.

Media: Village Voice
Review: <U+201C>Directed with his customary whip-smart precision by Christopher Ashley, the show offers the exhilarating combination of a set of feel-good stories with the hectic pace of breaking-news coverage. It doesn't dig deep: Its characters are rarely more than thumbnail sketches, and its lively music tickles the ear rather than catching the heart. But the overall shape of the event, told with smart skill and a generous spirit, has a sweet-tasting goodness to it.

Media: The Stage (UK)
Review: There are 10 new titles debuting across the year, but 'Come from Away' towers over the rest in terms of originality and daring...Sankoff and Hein's folk-based score has an easy affability and an earnest sincerity. Christopher Ashley's production gives the show a homespun honesty, and the 12-strong ensemble company, each of whom plays multiple characters, invest it with real feeling and emotion...A musical that tells an unusual, unfamiliar 9/11 story with tact and tremendous feeling.

Media: Daily Beast
Review: It is as simple in its focus as the acts of goodness and gratitude at its thematic core...It's not that 'Come From Away' doesn't approach tricky themes, but without much agonizing, it shines a positive light on them...From tragic source material, 'Come From Away' has wrought a work that emphasizes goodness and shared humanity. Whatever your cynicism levels around how that may sound on paper, resistance to the show-as-performed is pretty futile.

Media: StageZine
Review: <U+201C>Brilliant<U+2026>It is this show<U+2019>s ability to surprise and touch even the most cynical, jaded New York theatergoer that makes it so unusual and emotionally powerful<U+2026> In addition to the outstanding cast, expertly directed by Christopher Ashley, there is innovative choreography by Kelly Devine<U+2026>A musical that celebrates and glorifies humanity<U+2026>It<U+2019>s a new type of never-before-seen, uncharted musical territory much like 'Hamilton' was, and should also make musical-theater history.

Media: Cabaret Scenes
Review: May be the most inspirational, feel-good, 100 minutes of bang-for-the-buck ticket you can buy this season...Director Christopher Ashley is a master at keeping various personal stories moving at an energetic clip...While the actors are energetic and enthusiastic, there is no time for character depth. In addition, Sankoff and Hein<U+2019>s score fails to stand out with distinction, although the energy never sags...At its heart, 'Come From Away' is an extraordinary production.

Media: ZEALnyc
Review: As rousing, entertaining, and tremendously moving as any other show currently playing in New York...The show never gawks, sensationalizes, or trivializes the horrific events of that day. Rather, it renders the incomprehensible in real, richly human terms...If the show falls short in any way, it<U+2019>s in its ambition to do too much...Director Ashley<U+2019>s staging is, for the most part, slick and efficient, achieving the show<U+2019>s multitude of character and location changes with dazzling effectiveness.

Media: CitiTour
Review: <U+201C>Heartfelt but overly sentimental<U+2026>It tries to tell so many little stories that there<U+2019>s scant time to develop three-dimensional characters and substantial dramatic conflict. And the songs are pleasant but unmemorable<U+2026>Director Ashley and choreographer Devine keep the show focused and lively...Given the divided state of our country today, there<U+2019>s joy to be found in watching good folks look out each other. But it<U+2019>s not enough to send 'Come From Away' soaring to theatrical heights.

Media: Peconic Public Broadcasting
Review: <U+201C>Despite that it is really just an excellent off-Broadway musical trying to make it in the big-time world of Broadway, it<U+2019>s pretty darned good with some excellent music and a great cast of unknowns<U+2026>The music...is catchy and memorable and the ensemble cast who perform all the numbers are all incredibly talented<U+2026>An excellent musical<U+2026>A must small-time see.

Media: BackStage Barbie
Review: The score is energetic and homey, though you won't leave humming any particular tune. The songs really run together, not because they aren't memorable, but because the pace of the show is so rapid and is directed in such a way that the action is nonstop with seamless transitions...Ashley's direction and Devine's choreography are beautiful in their simplicity...I never once felt that I was watching a scene, but rather a continuous stream of action and emotion.

Media: Showbiz 411
Review: There<U+2019>s an indescribable charm to 'Come from Away' despite the fact that it<U+2019>s an ensemble, and that there are no big 'eleven o<U+2019>clock' songs. You will not come out humming...But I do think the ensemble is so well directed and energized that they manage to infect the audience with a real sense of pathos about the situation. Also, and this to thanks to Sankoff and Hein<U+2019>s book, there<U+2019>s nothing maudlin going on...The whole cast should be praised. This is a show with a lot of heart.

Media: BSonArts
Review: A very entertaining musical that is given a near pitch-perfect production...The show is full of humor and a company of 16 talented performers play multiple characters with aplomb and warmth. Most of the music is sung in ensemble and is staged with imagination and skill...Much of the music sounds the same but it blends perfectly with the story...As the show progressed...something was tugging at me. This was 9/11...I felt almost a sense of guilt for being seduced by the show.

Media: Broadway Showbiz
Review: This show has gorgeous music and lyrics. It is the CD I can<U+2019>t wait to own...This show is entertaining, uplifting and sweet. It was the perfect afternoon out and a show you can<U+2019>t help but love. I was tapping my feet to the fantastic Celtic rock music, and I had the best time. It is a must see...This show is very moving, and you might need tissues!

Media: Theater Life
Review: As reported, 'Come from Away,' appears to be the season<U+2019>s sleeper...Kelly Devine brings an easy buoyant charm to the choreography, and Christopher Ashley<U+2019>s direction leaves this humble tale in the hands of an earnest ensemble. But what is most refreshing is Irene Sankoff's and David Hein's book, music, and lyrics, which reveal grace in simplicity, and good faith in humankind.

Media: Frequent Business Traveler
Review: Will make you laugh and cry and restore your faith in humanity...This Canadian export, written by the husband and wife team of Irene Sankoff and David Hein, and directed by Christopher Ashley, comes at a time when divisiveness is far more prevalent than inclusivity, where countries talk about building walls rather than building bridges...It<U+2019>s one you won<U+2019>t want to miss. If you see just one show on Broadway this season, this should be it.

Media: Theater Pizzazz
Review: On
Review (Don't): March 21st, 2017=<U+201C>It<U+2019>s this truth that anchors  <U+2018>Come From Away,<U+2019> giving it a documentary-like power that is enhanced a thousand-fold by a driving musical score, the best ensemble acting you will see on any stage this season, and direction by Ashley that doesn<U+2019>t deserve a Tony Award, it deserves a Nobel Prize<U+2026>The result is a work that is, considering the events it depicts, restrained, delicate, and piercing<U+2026>A cry-fest and an absolutely joyful expression of what is best in the human animal: compassion.

Media: Center on the Aisle
Review: <U+201C>Yes, <U+2018>Come from Away<U+2019> is heartwarming. One cannot help but be moved and inspired by seeing the citizens of a tiny island band together and selflessly open their doors to help thousands of strangers. And yet something is missing. Although it is based on true, unique stories from 9/11, the musical seems to glaze over the actual tragedy of the events<U+2026>It would be a more successful show if it dug a little deeper for context and meaning.

Media: 90.7 WFUV
Review: A show that<U+2019>s both moving and exhilarating. A versatile, multicultural cast of 12 men and women of all ages and sizes portrays both the passengers and the townspeople, seamlessly switching from one to the other, singing with strong voices and moving with precision...The ensemble is truly the star. Credit director Christopher Ashley with creating an organic, yet thoroughly professional feeling...It was downright refreshing.

Media: Scene on Stage
Review: <U+201C>Rarely has altruism and compassion been as deeply explored and conveyed, much less in a hundred-minute musical...Music and lyrics mesh seamlessly, as the portrayals switch on a dime from townspeople to passengers and back again<U+2026>A uniformly excellent cast<U+2026>The show is in constant motion, with locations evoked by simple shifts in alignment of chairs. You<U+2019>re never in doubt about where you are, and for the duration of <U+2018>Come from Away<U+2019> you wouldn<U+2019>t want to be anywhere else.

Media: Escape Into Life
Review: Moved around stage with precision and theatrical acumen, the cast of twelve seems to be twice or three times the size...Throughout, there is high drive and a total lack of cynicism...Interaction between the players is loud, fast-paced, and mostly amiable...The lack of what might be called drama threatens to make the piece a minor effort...But it must be said, by the close, 'Come From Away<U+2019>s' simple-in-a-good-way, stubbornly empathic/positive vibe moves us with its integrity.

Media: Entertainment Weekly
Review: A feel-good musical about 9/11 ...Save for one woman who cannot get in touch with her NYC firefighter son, our travelers are, at worst, disoriented and inconvenienced...The music is confident and lively, and the lyrics keep the story moving...The double-and-more casting underscores 'Come From Away<U+2019>s' people-are-people theme. The point is struck somewhat heavily at times. But when the show threatens to feel pat, it helps to remember this all happened.

Media: The Washington Post
Review: for a previous production  Although the musical touches briefly on interesting aspects of the passengers<U+2019> feelings many of the self-narrated stories here fall into the lower-grade category of tales of inconvenience...It<U+2019>s as a unit that the dozen actors, with Ashley<U+2019>s intelligent guidance, ring the most urgent emotionality out of the material...If the book<U+2019>s mechanics unfold with too much sugar, the score has an infectious, gritty vitality.

Media: Variety
Review: for a previous production  A superb new show<U+2026>A moving, thoroughly entertaining tribute to international amity and the indomitable human spirit<U+2026>In only their second attempt at a musical, Sankoff and Hein maintain a hard-edged reality that old pros would envy<U+2026>Characters are types but never stereotypes...Ashley's crackerjack troupe of 12 skillfully shape-shifts among natives, passengers and officials back home...Each actor pulls full ensemble weight.

Media: San Diego Union-Tribune
Review: for a previous production  An inspired and highly original piece whose structure is wed beautifully to its story...Ashley directs the show with a graceful yet propulsive flow...The real-life backdrop serves the work<U+2019>s admirable authenticity, but one consequence is that the latter half feels short on conflict, as the characters grow more comfortable with each other and their plight<U+2026>And then there are flashes of theatrical magic<U+2026>In such quietly potent moments as those, 'Come From Away' takes wing.

Media: DC Metro Theater Arts
Review: for a previous production  What makes it different is also what makes it so very special. Sankoff and Hein seem to buck every rule of musical theatre and the result is one of the most refreshing pieces of art that I have seen in years. The folk and country influenced pop score is tuneful and the cast sings the hell out of it...It earns every tear, laugh, and cheer that it deservedly gets.

Media: DC Theatre Scene
Review: for a previous production  Ashley maintains a frenetic pace. He never lets off the gas, but, by the same token, rarely allows for stillness...Everything about 'Come From Away' is built for big-eyed impressiveness...It<U+2019>ll be so much fun that you<U+2019>ll hardly notice the paucity of pace variation and lack of overarching story through the speed and not-so-serious angle. Just let this new musical wash over you and you<U+2019>ll leave with a smile.

Media: BroadwayWorld
Review: for a previous production  The numerous songs move the story forward rather than stop it, and fit perfectly with a carefully constructed book...The cast is exceptional at creating, embracing, and putting forth a sense of community, while still standing out as individuals...'Come From Away' is a wholly satisfying evening of theatre - a bit of a throwback kind of musical, but with enough contemporary edge, and certainly relevance.

Media: The Globe and Mail
Review: for a previous production  With conversational lyrics and direct-address dialogue, 'Come From Away' has the feel of a documentary play...Despite 9/11 being always in the background, 'Come From Away' is a funny show...'Come From Away' may be a celebration of humanity <U+2013> but it is not starry-eyed...The accessible story, strong emotional core and gorgeous songwriting should not distract from how original and smart this gem of a musical is.

Media: Seattle Times
Review: for a previous production  An especially timely, meaningful balm to the benumbed psyche. A rousing, inspiring yet unpretentious show<U+2026><U+2019>Come From Away<U+2019> features a smartly choreographed acting ensemble loaded with versatility and presence<U+2026>This isn<U+2019>t, thankfully, a Hallmark Channel version of events<U+2026>It merits a broad audience for its thoughtful depiction of the kindness of strangers<U+2026>It honors our capacity for humble goodness and mutual empathy in the shadow of faith-shattering evil.

Media: On Stage Blog
Review: for a previous production  This is one of the best new shows I<U+2019>ve seen. The world is ready for this...The show includes real events and stories from the town and the actual passengers...The music and dialogue by Sankoff and Hein was absolutely superb, giving us laughs and tears constantly throughout. The direction couldn<U+2019>t have been any stronger; Ashley outdid himself with this piece...I can<U+2019>t really stress how important this show is to everyone.

Media: BroadwayWorld
Review: for a previous production  The best new, original musical I've ever seen...The production is brilliant directed by Christopher Ashley who perfectly paces the drama while bringing enough comedy to the piece to keep it from being overwhelming. Sankoff and Hein's score is enchanting, and full of songs that will stay with you long after you leave the theatre. You'll laugh, you'll cry, and you'll be a better person when you leave the theatre.

Media: Toronto Sun
Review: for a previous production  Here are real people and personal stories on both sides of the equation, all brought to life by only a dozen superb actors in a true ensemble. And by terrific music...The mood is energetic throughout, but switches seamlessly between celebratory and fierce. 'Come from Away' tells dozens of individual stories <U+2014> some with only a brilliant line or two <U+2014> and a general tale of the indelible bond created...This production is quick, smart, funny, deeply affecting.

Media: The Toronto Star
Review: for a previous production  A big-hearted, thoroughly enjoyable new musical...A talented and versatile cast all play multiple roles and switch between identities as locals and 'plane people,' underlining the message of shared humanity....It is far from subtle. But appreciation of it is greatly enhanced by the knowledge that the musical<U+2019>s storylines are based in truth...The show is full of engaging, surprising and often funny details as we are invited to look at the complexities of the influx of 'come from aways.'

Media: BroadwayWorld
Review: for a previous production  The best musical I've seen all year and possibly ever...The characters, story and above all the music of the show are infectious to the level of soul invading<U+2026>This highly emotional show is brilliantly directed by Ashley<U+2026>12 very gifted actors transform themselves from one persona to another with ease<U+2026>The story, the music, the performances; everything about it came together in a blissful m<U+00E9>lange of brilliance<U+2026>If you miss this one, you'll regret it for the rest of your theatrically subpar life.

Media: Seattle Post-Intelligencer
Review: for a previous production  One of the most engaging shows I<U+2019>ve ever seen, alternately upbeat and sad, boisterous and quiet. Every aspect of <U+2018>Come From Away<U+2019> is pitch-perfect, starting with the tightly written script and the infectious Celtic-rock music<U+2026>The 12-member cast is stellar<U+2026>It<U+2019>s the personal stories that make <U+2018>Come From Away<U+2019> such a powerful experience<U+2026>.A buoyant evening of first-rate theater.

Media: National Post
Review: for a previous production  A heart-warming show, but there<U+2019>s almost nothing sentimental about it. Both in its substance and in its treatment, it<U+2019>s outstandingly sensible. It drives but it doesn<U+2019>t rush. The cleverest but also the most honest thing about it may be the way it deploys its cast...It<U+2019>s ingenious, it<U+2019>s invigorating, and it<U+2019>s never confusing...The atmosphere is warm, but never insultingly folksy. The score, mostly tight and rockish, goes traditional for one ebullient sequence...It barrels seamlessly through.

Media: Entertainment Today
Review: for a previous production  Rarely over the decades have I seen an audience leap to its feet as quickly...A bravura production<U+2026>At the very center of the play, in terms of plot, timing and theme, is an incredibly powerful song called <U+2018>Prayer.<U+2019> In a sonic miracle, the hopes and fears of at least four major religions are harmonized. Director Christopher Ashley pulls together an incredibly diverse number of characters and subplots. He balances a wide range of emotions effectively<U+2026>This is an evening not to be missed.

Media: A different narrative about the impact of 9/11  Wanderlust
Review: See it if Celtic music & band are AMAZING. I didn't know the story & was interested to learn more about how people beyond NY/DC were impacted by 9/11
Review (Don't): Don't see it if I have mixed sentiments & can recognize that I am not the right audience demographic...see below=Also I was very fortunate to make it out of Tower 2 on 9/11, so every time the dialogue included a time/date stamp (e.g.,9/11 @ 10pm), I couldn't help but think about what victims,families & first responders were doing at that exact same time & I found myself getting increasingly agitated...When the passengers in the cast were complaining about the  discomforts  they had to endure--I was like  boo hoo  you had to sit for an extended period of time on a plane while people were trapped in rubble, scared, hurt & dead or splattered on Liberty Street because they had no choice but to jump. Boo hoo  you had to sleep in a crowded shelter while people were frantically trying to locate loved ones in complete chaos. Boo hoo  you were stuck & bored in Newfoundland & forced to eat weird food while the first responders were climbing on piles of burning rubble trying to find victims & body parts..Sure any one of the aforementioned would have gladly swapped places with any of the stranded....<U+00A0>Read more Read less=

Review: See it if you're overwhelmed by all the shows and this wasn't even on your radar - this heart-bursting show with 9/11 in the shadows will change you
Review (Don't): Don't see it if you don't like to cry for all of the right reasons.=Also I didn't want to see this and now I can't imagine ever skipping it. This is truly an ensemble piece with each character carrying their weight to deliver an exquisite piece of theater, zeroing in on the human condition, making you believe in the kindness and goodness of people. I was turned away initially with the 9/11 foundation, but this show celebrates the resilience and compassion of people, complete strangers, in moments where those two things are needed most. The actors wear multiple hats and you fall in love with every character they manifest. The songs are joyous, tuneful and foot stomping. The staging, while simple, manages to create beautiful pictures of ingenuity. This show has a lot to celebrate and you'd be absolutely remiss to deny yourself the pleasure of their company....<U+00A0>Read more Read less=

Review: See it if You want to see a show that is so relevant today. The show has an amazing ensemble that will make to laugh and cry.
Review (Don't): Don't see it if You are a cynic. Even then, you should watch this show, as it will change the way you see the world.=Also I have never seen a show that has given me such a wide range of emotions. CFA made me laugh and cry all at the same time. The story is so relevant today and covers so many issues in society such as racism, acceptance and feminism. The writers took so many risks and broke so many theatre conventions. But the end result is a musical that is so original and unique to Broadway. They managed to intertwine so many personal stories from real interviews on the 10th anniversary of 9/11. The story gets off to a slow start, but it really picks up towards the second half when some of the characters get their own songs.Christopher Ashley directs the story clearly and effectively. It was always easy to distinguish between the dozens of characters. The choreography was simple and folk-like, although some parts felt over choreographed. Every member of the 12 person ensemble deserves a Tony Award. Each of their performances are memorable, but Jenn Colella and Q Smith really shine!Go see CFA!...<U+00A0>Read more Read less=

No surprises here, and little character development.=Also What is surprising or even notable about humans being kind and generous to each other in the face of tragedy  These planes landed in Canada, not some remote uncivilized island. Clearly I'm in the minority with my opinion--people were up on their feet as soon as it was over cheering like it was a soccer match. There also was a frisson in the theatre before it began that suggested repeat viewers. There were so many stories about 9/11 with complicated plot twists and truly heartbreaking outcomes, I had to wonder why this is the story that was chosen. It would be better on the college circuit perhaps, or out of New York, where 9/11 is still an unhealed wound.Go see for yourself--I hope you can prove me wrong!...<U+00A0>Read more Read less=

Review (Don't): Don't see it if No reason not to. Go. ASAP. Once it officially opens, you won't get a ticket.=Also I knew nothing about this show. Strange title. Read a short blurb that told me it was the story (true) of the small town in Newfoundland (pop. 7000) that doubled overnight when planes were diverted there, unable to land at US airports after 9/11 and stayed, taken in by the town, for 4 days. Didn't excite me. I called my son, a theater student studying in FL and asked if he'd heard anything. He said  I heard it's great. If you can get a ticket - grab it, because after it opens, you won't be able to get one . I think he's right. I LOVED this show. 100 magical minutes w/ no intermission and when it's over - you'll wish it wasn't. A WONDERFUL cast of 12 (six men, six women) all playing multiple roles with quick onstage costume changes. All blending seamlessly into each part. They become who they play. All based (I presume) on real people in an extraordinary situation on 9/11 and its aftermath. Cleverly staged w/ a minimal set. Rousingly good. A magnificent achievement. An experience. GO...<U+00A0>Read more Read less=

Review: See it if you want to hear a  different  story connected to 9 11.
Review (Don't): Don't see it if you are looking for deep character development, memorable music, and good story telling=Also This is a show that will definitely tug at NY'ers hearts if you were here during one of the most tragic times in the cities and countries history. I would venture to say though, that is because of a visceral reaction NY'ers have to 9 11 not the story telling or music given here. The script tries to tell a story that was caused by the 9 11 tragedy but then backs off anything deeper than a song for each main character and nothing else. Too much is going on. So many stories, that when it is over, I felt little for any particular character. For a show that tries to say  we are NOT really  the 9 11 musical , it can't help but be that. The talent is good but Jenn Colella is the true stand out here, and also gets the deepest of the story telling handed to her. This woman has a broadway voice that fills the theater. Media: During previews Surprisingly moving, An unlikely topic for a musical, but it delivers, Great direction keeps the action moving, The consummate ensemble piece  Maria 24
Review: See it if You don't mind crying in the theater.
Review (Don't): Don't see it if You prefer big, splashy musicals.=Also I started out trying to resist this show. I thought,  I'm a New Yorker. I was here that day, and I know the real story of what happened.  So the experience of a bunch of travelers on 9/11 who were inconvenienced by the terrorist attacks didn't seem that relevant to me. But I went to see the show because of the positive word of mouth, and I'm glad I did.Yes, in some ways, the events depicted in Come From Away make up a footnote in the 9/11 story. But the experiences of the residents of Gander, Newfoundland, a small Canadian town, are told here with humor, emotion and sensitivity. The score ably supports the story, and the choreography (really, movement) reminds me of Hoggett's and is very effective. The characters are based on the real  plane people  who landed at Gander and were stranded there for five days, some 6,000 souls (plus a few critters). How the townspeople rallied to feed, clothe and house them all is an inspiring testament to resiliency in the face of disaster....<U+00A0>Read more Read less=

Review: See it if If you're Canadian, you may find something to connect to.
Review (Don't): Don't see it if If you're not Canadian. The tone shifts, poor lyrics and music, and unfocused storyline will put you to sleep.=Also I'll be honest. I thought this show would be amazing. I had heard so much hype about it that I thought it would be one of the best shows I'd ever seen. Most people seem to love it. So I encourage you to give it a try and judge it for yourself. Personally, I found very little in it to enjoy. Maybe three enjoyable songs, emotional hopping, undeveloped characters. Perhaps if the show were two acts and had more than just company numbers, there would be time for us to truly grow attached to the characters and do more than just celebrate them being  an islander . There were so many moments where I wanted an in depth look at the emotions the characters were feeling. But instead, it just went to another pointless up-tempo number that did nothing to further the plot. This was an unusually long review for me because I really really wanted to love this. And with all the love the show has been getting, I really feel like I owe a long explanation....<U+00A0>Read more Read less=

Review (Don't): Don't see it if 9/11 haunts you in difficult ways, you don't like Celtic-flavored music or you don't believe in the goodness of mankind=Also This is almost a perfect little gem. Wasn't sure it would translate to a Broadway house but it's going to be a hit. It drives forward with freight train force that sometimes goes too fast and sacrifices subtlety. But this is a big, bold story of how a group of people genuinely helped out each other under extraordinarily difficult circumstances and how the events of that day changed the world forever. It's a very timely message considering how the world is still trying to right itself 16 years later. It's a musical for everyone to see & learn from. So much better a history lesson than Hamilton ever offered (unlike Hamilton, no one in the audience fell asleep!). Go, enjoy and come out feeling some love for all mankind. It's terrific....<U+00A0>Read more Read less

Great staging, great sound, great lighting, AMAZING performances...I don't gush but I can not think of a single negative thing to say about this show. It showcases the beauty of the human condition and gives a gut wrenching peek into just how much the events of 9/11 affected not only all of America, but the rest of the world as well. I have seen well over 100 broadway shows and have never seen a crowd jump to it's feet faster. The lights came down at the end of the show and in the four second blackout the ENTIRE audience was on it's feet. No rushing for the doors, not sitting scattered throughout. This show was beautiful. And while some parts may seem a bit cheesy, most (if not all) of it really happened just as it's presented (I watched a documentary about it). The entire cast is fantastic and works seamlessly together. There are a lot of different characters that each actor can portray at any given time, so I can see how some audience members might find it a little confusing, but I had no trouble following along. Media: During previews Clever, Must see, Entertaining  John 7070
Date: See it if You like to feel something when you see a show.
Review: Don't see it if You want to over-intellectualize how and what you're feeling.
Review (Don't): Also I saw this a couple of nights ago, and I think some of the criticisms I see on this site are valid. I guess I see it differently. For me, the purpose of going to the theatre is to make me feel something - anger, sadness, happiness, or something I can't articulate, even. Come From Away made me - and I think almost everyone else in the audience - feel something. We felt sadness, laughter, shock, hope, love, and joy, among other things, all at various stages throughout the 100 minutes we were there. When was the last time I went to the theatre and felt even ONE of those  Let alone ALL of them The characters may be thinly drawn, but that didn't bother me at all. It's 100 minutes of theatrical creativity and imagination with a heart the size of a continent. So - all of this is to say: SEE IT. Now....<U+00A0>Read more Read less=

Date: See it if You want to tax yourself picking superlatives. Yes, it's THAT good
Review: Don't see it if You get choked up easily and admit that can be a little embarrassing when sitting next to strangers.
Review (Don't): Also OK, I'm sure there are people who know when their buttons are being pressed and resent it. And maybe there are some who thought it crossed the line at times into  predictability  or sentimentality. I was NOT one of those. 10/10 - from an absolutely breathtaking opening number/scene through to a Sully-like final scene (the stuff the movie ran with the credits.) Just a jaw-dropping show - somebody finally figured out an almost perfect way to  frame  9/11. There are a couple of Broadway world reviews on this site. One put it better than I ever could:  If you miss this one, you'll regret it for the rest of your theatrical life.  (Well, you won't really know what you've missed, but trust me - you'll have missed perfection.) And I guess because of the subject matter, it isn't $500/ticket ... yet - i.e., the $50/ticket we spent to be in the last row of the Orch. was among the best $100 I've ever spent. P.S. If you're with someone who isn't moved and you're not committed, dump him or her....<U+00A0>Read more Read less=

You dislike actors playing multiple characters or do not want to see the beauty that can some in fate=Also This score is not a typical musical score - it feels more like Last a Ship. The company is remarkable in playing dozens of people each. The director had allowed the audience to exprience the emotions of the people involved - to a point where the monotony of 28 hours on a plane draws out so one can experience it. They are wise in focusing on a handful of true and remarkable stories while establishing the feeling of 900 people trying to care for an extra 7000. It touches in the tragedy of 9:11 but while celebrating love and care and what unique relationships can happen when people are thrust together - it might need a bit of trimming as this was first preview but I left filled with positive feelings and in this day and age that is a gift....<U+00A0>Read more Read less=

Media: For a previous production Funny, Uplifting, Great acting, Must see, Emotional, heartfelt, & brilliant  Allison 36
Review: See it if You want to see a truly uplifting, resonant and funny show that will restore your faith in humanity. Brilliant acting & staging - must see!
Review (Don't): Don't see it if You don't like stories based on true events or you prefer shows with lots of spectacle, jazz hands and dancing.=Also This review is for the D.C. pre-Broadway production. Although the prospect of a musical dealing with 9/11 sounds off-putting at first, it's really not about that, so don't let that stop you from seeing it. I certainly did not expect to laugh as much as I did at this show, but there are emotional moments too. The cast is incredible. Each one plays multiple characters in the town of Gander and people on the planes. They are able to effortlessly switch between playing different characters with different accents constantly, yet you never lose track of who they are at any given time. The music is also fabulous - folksy Newfoundland music mixed with other genres. It was so good I saw it twice and can't wait to catch it again on Broadway. I think it has a good shot for the 2017 Tony for best musical....<U+00A0>Read more Read less=
